title: Monday, 21st November, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

PM11:01am

PM11:02am

11:02 am
PM11:02am

PM11:02am

11:02 am

PM11:02am

https://www.ft.com...-9cb3-bb8207902122

11:02 am
PM11:03am

The first venture capital fund dedicated to commercialising space has won the backing of the UK government with a £50m investment pledge from the British Business Bank.

The launch of the £80m Seraphim Space Fund comes as the government prepares to publish figures that will show that growth in the UK space sector is outpacing the wider economy.

PM11:03am

I'm pretty sure Williams runs this Seraphim thing

PM11:03am

Ah yes, I'm right

11:03 am
PM11:04am

Building upon the smart capital ethos that has always underpinned the Seraphim strategy, the
Seraphim Space Fund pioneers a multi-corporate backer model, harnessing the collective experience
and expertise of leading space industry incumbents to provide the start-ups the fund will invest in with
unparalleled access to and guidance from the top echelons of the space sector.
The space focus of the latest Seraphim Fund was the brainchild of David Williams, CEO of UK quoted
satellite operator Avanti Communications Group plc. David, who joined the fund as Chairman of the
Advisory Board, recognised the need for a venture capital fund to help foster the most innovative
‘space-tech’ companies at a time of unprecedented change within the space industry. The Seraphim
Space Fund was conceived as a way of nurturing promising space-related start-ups in a bid to support
the ambitious targets of tripling the UK space sector by 2030.

PM11:04am

Which is great

PM11:04am

Except we'd also like David to be concentrating on his day job

11:15 am

PM11:16am

BE11:16am

Go on then.

11:16 am
PM11:16am

Euro strengthing a tad this morning

PM11:16am

And the GBK pretty stable

PM11:16am

But in the wake of Trump...

11:16 am
PM11:16am

Actually, let me get Simon Derrick to explain

PM11:17am

BNY Mellon

PM11:17am

One price move in the currency markets that has not followed the standard yield related script in recent weeks has been the sharp decline seen in EUR/GBP. To understand what might be going on it is worth considering the moves seen in the pair since the start of the year.

11:17 am
PM11:17am

lthough there had been some divergence between EUR/GBP and the changes seen in the benchmark 2-year German/UK government debt yield gap in the immediate aftermath of the announcement of the EU referendum in February, by mid-March the relationship between yield pick-up and currency performance was very much back in play. Indeed, despite the extremity of the moves seen in the aftermath of the referendum itself, it is arguable that this relationship held all the way through the summer. However, Prime Minister Theresa May's announcement at the Conservative party conference at the start of October that the UK was set to trigger Article 50 by March of next year (setting in train the process for the UK to formally leave the EU) saw the currency pair begin to perform in a very different way. Now the widening of the yield gap in favour of the UK (triggered by a rise in Gilt yields) was accompanied by a sharp decline in the value of GBP. This was as clear an indication as possible that investors were now starting to factor in political risk into their thinking about GBP and that it now outweighed the yield advantage available.

PM11:17am

GBP remained out of favour until the start of this month. However, since then there has been an interesting development. Despite the fact that that the 2-year German/UK yield gap moved against the UK from late October onwards (only really turning round late last week), GBP has appreciated sharply against the EUR. The first signs of strength for GBP emerged on November 3 and coincided with a high court ruling that parliament must vote on leaving the EU. However, it is noticeable that the big move up for GBP has come in the aftermath of the US presidential election. It is also noticeable that this has coincided with a renewed focus on the potential outcome of the Italian referendum on December 4 with the clearest evidence for this coming from the 23 bp widening out in the yield gap between Italian 2-year government paper and the equivalent German debt.

PM11:17am

With this in mind it is worth noting two other points. Firstly, while there has been a widening out in both the 2-year Austrian/German and French/German yield gaps, these have proved modest so far (5 bp and 3 bp respectively). This indicates neither the re-run of the Austrian presidential election (set for December 4) nor the commencement of the French presidential race (see headlines) appear to be weighing on sentiment so far. Secondly, despite a flurry of UK related news over the past few days, 2-year Gilt yields have remained relatively stable, as has EUR/GBP. This is helpful as it helps indicate that the focus for the moment is on developments in Italy. More generally, it also indicates that after a year that has seen both the EU referendum and the US presidential election catch the market collectively off guard, investors are now starting to give more attention to political risk.

11:17 am
PM11:18am

And some UBS

PM11:18am

Will the EUR par the US dollar?

PM11:18am

A pressing question

11:18 am
PM11:18am

Not your 2015 dollar rally
Over the past year we have actively urged investors to fade dollar rallies. But this time,
things are slightly different. Yes, once again the market expects the US economy to
significantly outpace key counterparties as a very large gap between US yields and
European yields reflects. And yes, once again dollar strength is driving oil prices lower.
Of course, lower oil and a stronger dollar will deliver softer inflation outcomes. But,
crucially, the hit from tighter financial conditions to equities and credit has been tiny (if
any). This is because the market expects the new US administration to provide a strong
offset in the form of fiscal, tax and regulatory easing. In other words, this dollar rally
reflects hopes for an asymmetric US-centric growth shock.

PM11:18am

US growth boost uncertain – but increasingly in the price
It will take some time until we have enough information on the new administration’s
planned measures, potential growth impact and political feasibility. Until then, the
market will reflect “scenarios” or sketches of outcomes. We have created a framework
that matches the (positive and negative) effects of fiscal (and structural) loosening on
the dollar, stocks and bonds. It helps us back-out the market’s expectations: with 10yr
yields at around 2.30%, equities 2% higher than pre-election levels and the dollar 3%
stronger, the market is pricing the prospect of a package that leads to a cumulative
budget expansion of a bit less than 1 trillion dollars, leading to a moderate but
consistent GDP boost over several years. This broad market expectation is not
excessive enough to fade yet. Still, we think it is fair to argue, that current EUR
levels reflect a generous amount of US growth optimism.

PM11:19am

Can't help but agree with that last point

11:19 am
PM11:19am

EUR weakness, however, goes beyond US growth; political risk is at play
In fact, to stay true to our framework, the EUR has sold off more than we would have
expected relative to the moves in bonds and stocks and the average level dollar
strengthening against majors and EMs. EUR's underperformance is partly due to the
disruptive prospect of the French elections, the Italian referendum, and other upcoming
political events in the Eurozone – particularly in light of the recent streak of surprises in
events such as the Greek referendum, the UK EU vote and the US presidential election.

PM11:19am

EUR/$ parity unlikely; signposts for a EUR/$ recovery
We have recently lowered our EUR/$ trajectory but our forecasts envisage upside from
current levels, and we do not expect to see parity. At current levels, and with vol having
risen, we think selling EUR/USD downside could be attractive. In our view, the EUR is
cheap and supported by a very solid current account surplus. Market-based growth
expectations for the Eurozone are suppressed relative to the resilience the growth data
exhibits. And we believe a US growth boost is increasingly in the price. In principle,
conditions seem to be falling into place for the EUR/$ to bottom, but uncertainty is
high. We see three key pivot points/signposts ahead: a) Policies from the new US
administration. Measures that decently boost GDP growth (e.g. 0.5% per year for a
number of years) could lead to a further significant dollar rally. b) The French primaries.
Over the next week we will have more information on the right-wing candidate that
may end up confronting Marine Le Pen in next year’s election. At the time of writing,
Sarkozy, who has in the past polled reasonably low in popular preference, has dropped
out. We think candidates with high approval rates vs Mrs Le Pen would reduce nearterm
uncertainty and boost the EUR, and vice versa. c) The Italian referendum outcome.
We will write on this in more detail in the days to come, but in our view markets should
not treat this as a binary event. We believe a "no" vote could be potentially
destabilizing near-term but could help avoid tail-risk outcomes closer to the upcoming
election in 2018 more easily than a "yes" vote.

PM11:19am

That's from Themos Fiotakis and team

11:19 am
undefined
BE11:20am

Heading into the miners specifically ......

BE11:20am

.......... Goldman pushing commodities.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

"It is tempting to blame the sharp post-election rally in industrial metals prices on President-elect Trump’s platform of lower taxation and higher public spending on infrastructure. Instead, we would argue this rally was a continuation of a reflation trend put in place at the start of 2016 by the Chinese through credit stimulus aimed at infrastructure projects and policy driven supply curtailments in coal where they have 50% of global production. Although this was policy driven and a Trump victory increases the odds of further fiscal policy stimulus, these policy actions all act as a tailwind on a US economy in the later stages of a business cycle pushing near capacity."

BE11:21am

That's the first par of the relatively readable, for Goldman, exec summary.

BE11:21am

But I'll cut to the intro bullets for the wider picture.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Recommending overweight commodities and long enhanced GSCI. Historically, when the US and Chinese output gap closes and inflation begins to rise, this has been a buy signal for commodities. We believe the recent reacceleration in global PMIs suggests commodity markets are entering a cyclically stronger environment.

Supply restrictions from policy actions should benefit oil, coking coal and nickel in the near term while economic reductions should boost natural gas and zinc. Accordingly, we are upgrading our GSCI returns forecast to +9.0% +11.0%+6.0% on a 3, 6 and 12 month basis from -2.0%+1.7%+8.3%.

BE11:22am

(Not sure what a long enhanced GSCI is. Answers to the left welcome.)

BE11:22am

The increased likelihood of an OPEC cut motivates our near-term forecast upgrade. Stronger than expected demand growth and lower production from high-cost countries increase our confidence that the global oil market will shift into deficit by 2H17 even with OPEC production above current levels. Thus, there is now a stronger incentive for OPEC producers to halt inventory growth in 1H17 and normalize the current high level of inventories with a short-duration production cut.
We think a cut should generate backwardation – helping OPEC grow market share by sidelining higher-cost producers – and reduce oil price volatility – increasing the valuation of their debt and equity.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Higher commodity prices likely to improve financial conditions. Commodity prices are correlated with the accumulation and de-accumulation of EM excess savings. Unlike in the 1970s, more sophisticated financial markets in the 2000s were able to transform the excess savings into greater global liquidity that increased asset values, lowered interest rates and improved credit conditions that spanned the globe. Weak commodity prices in 2015 and 2016 acted as a drag on financial conditions.

BE11:23am

A bullish dollar view is not incompatible with a bullish commodity view. We expect that the positive roll return from backwardation in commodities will offset the downward pressure from a strengthening dollar, as has historically been the case.

BE11:23am

(Thank you @Mouselet. You can come back tomorrow.)

11:23 am
BE11:24am

We upgrade our 3/6/12-month iron ore price forecasts to $65/63/55 per tonne. Steel consumption is more resilient than expected and demand for iron ore is likely to be supported further by incremental restocking across the steel supply chain. Further, the pace of supply growth has slowed as a result of delayed capital expenditure and operational challenges.

BE11:24am

So there we go. Thirteen analysts named on that note, which only runs for 23 pages including disclaimers.

PM11:25am

(We never said we were fixing text wrap. We cut and paste from too many different sources to guarantee that. Sorry.)

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Meanwhile, on the stock specific view, Anglo has a jolly to South Africa this week.

BE11:28am

There is a clear shift in emphasis with less focus on divestments and a return to the 2013/14 strategic goals based around operational efficiencies and capital allocation. The company is still open to disposals if the "right offers" are received, but the balance sheet is moving to a far healthier position than 12 months ago. Nickel and coking coal could still be part of the portfolio over the medium term.

PM11:28am

I guess when your stock price has risen five fold, the pressure does ease somewhat

11:28 am
BE11:28am

You can be lucky or good. I'm still unsure which Cutifani is.

BE11:29am

[We think] reducing the company's SA asset exposure could be the key to driving a re-rating from here (lower EM exposure, simpler business structure) and the company is open to selling SA assets (and potentially consolidating some assets into a single vehicle). According to management, any deals would need to create value for all shareholders and the company would want some agreement/relaxation over extracting cash proceeds from South Africa.

BE11:29am

Guidance remains what it was, tho.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Capex and net debt: 2017 total capex still guided at below $2.5bn and the company sees ~$2.5bn as the future level of sustainable capex (excluding growth capex). No change to year end net debt target of below $10bn (we expect closer to $9bn).
■ Dividend: target to re-introduce by end 2017 with first payment in H1 2018. If prices remain high a restart six months earlier is possible. The company will adopt a payout policy.

BE11:30am

You can look at the presentations yourself here, if you wish: http://www.angloam...presentations/2016

BE11:31am

Though you don't get a week in the Hyatt Regency Johannesburg to think about them.

This Mitie thing has been hit hard

Mitie Group PLC (MTO:LSE): Last: 188.59, down 21.41 (-10.19%), High: 192.50, Low: 165.00, Volume: 5.45m

http://www.investe...1611210700106522P/

BE11:33am

11:33 am
PM11:33am

PM11:34am

Despite real losses per share of almost 30p

PM11:34am

11:34 am
PM11:35am

40%!

BE11:35am

Hospital services always seemed an odd direction for Mitie to move. What's the benefit of having hospital wards cleaners managed by the same people who employ the folk doing the tarmac on the road outside?

BE11:35am

Remember there's a new CEO coming in here to try and sort this mess out.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Barclays incoming.

BE11:36am

MITIE (UW, TP 166p) – Interim results worse than already lowered expectations – MTO has reported 1H adjusted operating profit of £35.4m, a yoy decline of 39% vs September guidance for a 20-30% decline in operating profit. Outlook reports “underlying earnings for FY17 are expected to be below management’s previous expectations”. Given we had been under the impression at the time of MTO’s September trading update that their revised guidance was POST restructuring costs but today adjusted operating profit is reported PRE restructuring costs of £6m, underlying performance is even worse than we expected and also has implications for FY18 forecasts where our current yoy increase of £10m in operating profit vs FY17 is solely based on a reversal of FY17 restructuring costs. Reflecting the significant profit decline and negative outlook, interim DPS has been cut to 4.0p, -26% vs prior year and the first dividend cut in Mitie’s history. Operating cash conversion of 108% is above the target of 80% but net debt has increased by £53m, resulting in period-end net debt/EBITDA of 1.9x vs 1.2x at 31-Mar-16. The Healthcare business has been placed “under strategic review”, which isn’t much progress vs what we were told in September, although we finally have a long overdue write-off to reflect the performance of this business with £107.1m of goodwill and £10.1m of acquisition intangibles now fully written off. Further potential liabilities in relation to this business are operating losses up to the date of withdrawal and potential one-off closure costs if a buyer cannot be found. Prior to any potential forecast adjustments, MTO trades on a CY2017 PE of 10.0x, falling to 9.4x in CY2018.

BE11:36am

And Canaccord.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

Estimate Changes: H1 EBITA of £35m is below our expectation of £41m due to more significant losses than anticipated in Care and as a result we have reduced our expectations for FY17 by a further 15% to £92m, with H2 seasonally stronger and likely to benefit from £10m of incremental cost savings generated by staff-led restructuring. Although there has been some improvement in the past two months it remains too soon to predict an immediate bounce back in discretionary project work given the market backdrop, and gross margins may come under further pressure into FY18 as another year of NLW wage costs must be absorbed by the Customer base alongside potential additional cost from the introduction of the Apprenticeship Levy. As a result we have also reduced estimates for FY18 by 18%, which should see some benefit vs FY17 from reduced losses in Care post-withdrawal. In line with the fall in earnings the interim divided has been cut and we anticipate 2.1x earnings cover (DPS of 8p) will be the target for the full year, resulting in a 35% reduction to earlier expectations.

BE11:37am

Looking forward: We maintain that the underlying FM business is still attractive and that there are opportunities for Mitie, as the largest player in the UK, to benefit from customer cost pressure through more outsourcing opportunities and that there is significant scope for self-help within the business. Despite an expansion in longer term receivables in the past few years, Mitie has produced £50m of FCF on average every year for the past decade, which following the exit of Care, and a lack of any major contract specific issues should offer a degree of underpin to the shares. Similarly, given the trading of FM and PM peers a long term margin of 5% (Historic Group targets of 5-6%) looks achievable and with the shares at an EV/Sales (ex Care) of 0.5x, any major collapse in the shares does provide a longer term opportunity.
That said, with the shares likely to fall in line with estimates today, uncertainty remaining around trading in FY18, new management likely to review future strategy in early 2017, and speculation likely around leverage given potential cash costs to exit Care (avg net debt/EBITDA of c2.4x expected) leave us less positive in the short term, moving our Target down to 195p (10x FY18 PE) and rating to HOLD.

BE11:39am

(@Pharma: absolutely. But as we've discussed here ad nauseum, this sector seems to rely on mispricing. You under-bid and make little or no margin on ten contracts then make an absolute killing on one that's been mispriced the opposite way.)

undefined
11:48 am
BE11:49am

Speaking of profit warnings .........

Essentra PLC (ESNT:LSE): Last: 402.10, down 92.2 (-18.65%), High: 412.50, Low: 383.90, Volume: 1.27m
BE11:49am

As in, Filtrona.

11:49 am
PM11:49am

Ouch

BE11:50am

Changed its name from Filtrona to Essentra to get away from the idea that it just makes cigarette filters.

BE11:50am

But everyone still calls it "the company previously known as Filtrona," so .... moderate success.

11:50 am
PM11:50am

Has it branched out from cigarette filters.?

BE11:51am

It does healthcare packaging as well, I think. And all sorts of other filters.

BE11:51am

It's the former and the latter that's gone wrong.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Here comes Deutsche to explain.

BE11:52am

Essentra has published a profit warning in an unscheduled trading update, lowering the EBITA guidance range for FY-16 from £155-165m to £137-142m. Company consensus EBITA for FY-16 stands at c.£159m (DBe £158m) and as such the mid-point of the range implies a cut of c.-12%. Looking out to FY-17, if we assume no growth vs. the mid-point of the FY-16 range and take out c.£20m for Porous, this would imply a cut of c.-23% vs. Company consensus of £156m (DBe £156m).
The previous range was set before the EU referendum and was confirmed at the H1-16 results in July at which point there would have been a c.£5-10m benefit from FX translation and it was at analysts’ discretion how much of the FX was taken into account.

BE11:53am

The majority of the cut is again due to HPC and Filtration. In HPC packaging, they say that the three facilities in the US and UK which experienced integration issues in H1 continue to perform at improved levels to those seen earlier in the year, but are not delivering the required uplift, and that has meant lower growth as well.
In Filters, the company is talking about 1) slower than expected ramp up of new work; 2) transfer of a particular line of existing business from the US to Asia has been delayed until early 2017; and 3) weakness in China.
On Component Solutions, the company has said that trading is in line with expectations with growth in Continental Europe and Asia strong, the UK and the US “showing early encouraging signs of slowing the revenue declines evident in H1” 2016. Pipe Protection remains subdued and Extrusion has continued to grow.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Coming into today on our forecasts (in line with Company consensus), Essentra was trading on 11x 2017E P/E, 9x EV/EBITA, 4% dividend yield and 8% FCF yield. The stock is clearly inexpensive but this will in our view lead to another double digit leg down in the share price.

BE11:55am

(@fjp73: I've heard variations of that Sainsbury story every week for about a year but have found no-one able to put a name to it. If anyone can and fancies a chat, they're very welcome.)

undefined

BE11:55am

BE11:56am

11:56 am

BE11:58am

BE11:59am
